# Source: https://biomejs.dev/guides/migrate-eslint-prettier/

# Migrate from ESLint and Prettier 

Biome provides dedicated commands to ease the migration from ESLint and Prettier.

If you don't want to know the details, just run the following commands:

<figure class="frame is-terminal not-content">
<pre data-language="shell"><code>1biome migrate eslint --write2biome migrate prettier --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title"></span><span class="sr-only">Terminal window</span></figcaption>
</figure>

## Migrate from ESLint

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Migrate from ESLint"]](#migrate-from-eslint)

Many Biome linter rules are inspired by or identical to the ESLint rules or the rules of an ESLint plugin. We handle some ESLint plugins such as [TypeScript ESLint](https://typescript-eslint.io/), [ESLint JSX A11y](https://github.com/jsx-eslint/eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y), [ESLint React](https://github.com/jsx-eslint/eslint-plugin-react), and [ESLint Unicorn](https://github.com/sindresorhus/eslint-plugin-unicorn). However, Biome has its own naming convention for its rules. Biome uses `camelCaseRuleName` while ESLint uses `kebab-case-rule-name`. Moreover, Biome has often chosen to use different names to better convey the intent of its rules. The source of a rule can be found on the page describing the rule. You can also find the equivalent Biome rule from an ESLint rule using the [dedicated page](/linter/rules-sources).

To ease the migration, Biome provides the `biome migrate eslint` subcommand. This subcommand will read your ESLint configuration and attempt to port its settings to Biome. The subcommand is able to handle both the legacy and the flat configuration files. It supports the `extends` field of the legacy configuration and loads both shared and plugin configurations. For flat configuration files, the subcommand will attempt to search for JavaScript extension only (`js`, `cjs`, `mjs`) to be loaded into Node.js. The subcommand needs Node.js to load and resolve all the plugins and `extends` configured in the ESLint configuration file. The subcommand also migrates `.eslintignore`.

Given the following ESLint configuration:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="json"><code>1,8  &quot;rules&quot;: ,11  &quot;overrides&quot;: [12    17    }18  ]19}</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">.eslintrc.json</span></figcaption>
</figure>

And the following Biome configuration:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="json"><code>17  }8}</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">biome.json</span></figcaption>
</figure>

Run the following command to migrate your ESLint configuration to Biome.

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-182)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-183)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-184)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-185)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-186)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1npx @biomejs/biome migrate eslint --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1pnpm exec biome migrate eslint --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1bunx --bun biome migrate eslint --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome migrate eslint --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1yarn exec biome migrate eslint --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

The subcommand overwrites your initial Biome configuration. For example, it disables `recommended`. This results in the following Biome configuration:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="json"><code>1,3  &quot;linter&quot;: ,13      &quot;style&quot;: ,19      &quot;suspicious&quot;: 24    }25  },26  &quot;javascript&quot;: ,27  &quot;overrides&quot;: [28     } }31    }32  ]33}</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">biome.json</span></figcaption>
</figure>

For now, `biome migrate eslint` doesn't support configuration written in YAML.

By default, Biome doesn't migrate inspired rules. You can use the CLI flag `--include-inspired` to migrate them.

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-187)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-188)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-189)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-190)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-191)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1npx @biomejs/biome migrate eslint --write --include-inspired</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1pnpm exec biome migrate eslint --write --include-inspired</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1bunx --bun biome migrate eslint --write --include-inspired</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome migrate eslint --write --include-inspired</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1yarn exec biome migrate eslint --write --include-inspired</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

Note that you are unlikely to get exactly the same behavior as ESLint because Biome has chosen not to implement some rule options or to deviate slightly from the original implementation.

Since ESLint takes VCS ignore files into account, we recommend that you enable Biome's [VCS integration](/guides/integrate-in-vcs).

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)Caution

Some plugins or shared configurations may export an object with a cyclic reference. Biome may fail to load such a configuration.

## Migrate from Prettier

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Migrate from Prettier"]](#migrate-from-prettier)

Biome tries to match the Prettier formatter as closely as possible. However, Biome uses different defaults for its formatter. For example, it uses tabs for indentation instead of spaces. You can easily migrate to Biome by running `biome migrate prettier --write`.

Given the following Prettier configuration:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="json"><code>18      }9  ]10}</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">.prettierrc.json</span></figcaption>
</figure>

Run the following command to migrate your Prettier configuration to Biome.

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-192)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-193)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-194)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-195)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-196)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1npx @biomejs/biome migrate prettier --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1pnpm exec biome migrate prettier --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1bunx --bun biome migrate prettier --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome migrate prettier --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1yarn exec biome migrate prettier --write</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

This results in the following Biome configuration:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="json"><code>1,11  &quot;organizeImports&quot;: ,12  &quot;linter&quot;:  },13  &quot;javascript&quot;: 25  },26  &quot;overrides&quot;: [27    32    }33  ]34}</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">biome.json</span></figcaption>
</figure>

The subcommand needs Node.js to load JavaScript configurations such as `.prettierrc.js`. `biome migrate prettier` doesn't support configuration written in JSON5, TOML, or YAML.

Since Prettier takes VCS ignore files into account, we recommend that you enable Biome's [VCS integration](/guides/integrate-in-vcs).

[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)Edit page](https://github.com/biomejs/website/edit/main/src/content/docs/guides/migrate-eslint-prettier.mdx)
